Abstract: This study embarks on an exploration of the intricate interplay between blood cell disorders and genetic mutations, tracing a path from clinical manifestations to molecular underpinnings and back. Focusing on hemoglobinopathies, G6PD deficiency, and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, the research delves into the genetic mutations and somatic alterations that drive these conditions. By examining the role of Darwinian selection in shaping the prevalence and distribution of these genetic traits, the study provides insights into the evolutionary pressures that have influenced human genetics. Through an autobiographical lens, the narrative intertwines personal experiences with scientific discovery, offering a unique perspective on the journey from clinical observation to genetic analysis. This approach not only highlights the advancements in understanding the genetic basis of blood disorders but also underscores the dynamic relationship between genes and their phenotypic expressions. The findings contribute to a deeper comprehension of the genetic landscape of hematological diseases, paving the way for novel therapeutic strategies and personalized medicine approaches.
